structured_data.title: Gene Program Functional Analysis for Astrocytoma

context.tissue: brain, cerebral cortex, white matter tracts

programs.description: Ionotropic and metabotropic glutamate receptor-mediated excitatory synaptic transmission and long-term potentiation/depression. Comprises NMDA receptor subunits (GRIN1, GRIN2A, GRIN2B), AMPA receptor subunits (GRIA1), metabotropic glutamate receptors (GRM5, GRM7), and associated scaffolding and signaling machinery including calcium-calmodulin-dependent protein kinases (CAMK2A, CAMK2B), presynaptic vesicle machinery (SYT1, SYT14, RIMS1, RIMS2), and postsynaptic density proteins (DLG2, GRIP1, GRIP2). In glioblastoma and astrocytoma, peritumoral neurons exhibit enhanced glutamatergic signaling with increased dendritic spine density and elevated synaptic inputs, leading to increased neuronal excitability and seizure susceptibility.

atomic_biological_processes.name: NMDA receptor-mediated calcium influx and signaling

citations.notes: GRIN1 and GRIN2A encode critical NMDA receptor subunits mediating calcium-dependent synaptic plasticity
GRIN1 encodes NMDA receptor subunit 1, a critical component of glutamate receptor channels
NMDA receptor dysfunction contributes to altered dendritic structure in tumor-adjacent neurons

atomic_biological_processes.name: Activity-dependent synaptic strengthening through AMPA receptor trafficking

citations.notes: GRIA1-containing AMPA receptors show activity-dependent trafficking in peritumoral neurons

atomic_biological_processes.name: Metabotropic glutamate receptor signaling

citations.notes: GRM5 and GRM7 couple to G-protein signaling modulating synaptic strength and plasticity

atomic_biological_processes.name: Calcium-dependent kinase signaling

citations.notes: CAMK2B (calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II) regulates neuron migration and synaptic plasticity
CAMK2A autophosphorylation regulates synaptic plasticity and memory formation

atomic_biological_processes.name: Presynaptic vesicle release and active zone organization

citations.notes: SYT1 and associated proteins regulate synaptic vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release
RIMS proteins organize the presynaptic active zone and control readily releasable pool

atomic_cellular_components.name: Postsynaptic density organization at glutamatergic synapses

citations.notes: DLG2 and GRIP proteins organize postsynaptic glutamate receptors and signaling complexes

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced glutamatergic signaling and synaptic transmission
Increased dendritic spine density in peritumoral neurons
Elevated neuronal excitability and reduced seizure threshold
Dysregulated calcium homeostasis in glioma-adjacent neurons
Enhanced long-term potentiation in circuits containing glioma
programs.evidence_summary: Multiple genes in this program show altered expression in peritumoral cortex adjacent to glioblastoma, with computational models demonstrating that modest increases in glutamatergic synaptic inputs double spike output rates and substantially increase seizure susceptibility. Paroxysmal depolarizing shifts characteristic of pre-ictal activity are detected prior to clinical seizure onset in a subset of glioma patients, correlating with upregulated glutamatergic signaling markers. This program represents a core mechanism through which glioma growth induces circuit hyperexcitability and seizure pathogenesis.

citations.notes: Comprehensive characterization of aberrant neural activity in peritumoral cortex with computational modeling
Glioma-induced glutamate elevation and altered neuronal excitability
NMDA receptor disease-associated variants and functional roles
GRIN1 as critical NMDA receptor component
Glutamate receptor signaling and synaptic plasticity mechanisms
PSD-95 family proteins and Homer organize postsynaptic density

programs.description: Fast inhibitory GABAergic synaptic transmission mediated by ionotropic GABA-A receptors and slower inhibition through metabotropic GABA-B receptors. GABA-A receptor subunits (GABRA2, GABRB1, GABRG2) form chloride channels mediating fast inhibition, while GABBR2 (metabotropic GABA-B receptor) couples to G-protein pathways. This program maintains excitatory-inhibitory balance in neural circuits. In astrocytoma, dysfunction of GABAergic inhibition contributes to hyperexcitability and seizure susceptibility through reduced inhibitory tone and altered interneuron function.

atomic_biological_processes.name: Ionotropic GABA-A receptor-mediated fast inhibition

citations.notes: Reduced GABAergic inhibition contributes to peritumoral neuronal hyperexcitability

atomic_biological_processes.name: Metabotropic GABA-B receptor signaling and presynaptic inhibition

citations.notes: GABBR2 metabotropic signaling provides presynaptic inhibition and homeostatic regulation

predicted_cellular_impact: Reduced inhibitory synaptic transmission in peritumoral cortex
Impaired excitatory-inhibitory balance leading to circuit hyperexcitability
Increased seizure susceptibility through loss of inhibitory tone
Dysfunction of interneuron-mediated circuit regulation
Enhanced vulnerability to glutamate-induced excitotoxicity
programs.evidence_summary: GABAergic inhibition is compromised in the peritumoral region of glioblastomas, with reduced GABA reuptake by astrocytes and impaired interneuron function contributing to the shift toward hyperexcitability. Inflammatory mediators in the tumor microenvironment preferentially affect GABAergic neurons, further disrupting the balance. The presence of spike-wave discharges and high gamma-band activity in glioma-bearing animals indicates synchronous firing consistent with reduced inhibition.

citations.notes: GABAergic dysfunction in peritumoral cortex
Excitatory-inhibitory imbalance in tumor-associated seizures
GABBR2 and GABAergic signaling in neurological function
GABAergic machinery essential for inhibitory transmission

programs.program_name: Voltage-Gated Ion Channels and Neuronal Excitability Control
programs.description: L-type and non-L-type voltage-gated calcium channels (CACNA1C, CACNA1D, CACNA1E) and potassium channels (KCNQ3, KCNC2, KCNJ3, KCNMA1, KCNMB2) that determine neuronal resting potential, action potential generation, and intrinsic excitability. CACNA1C is a pleiotropic psychiatric disease gene affecting neural circuit development. Potassium channels provide repolarizing conductances that regulate frequency-dependent firing and suppress neuronal hyperexcitability. In glioma-adjacent neurons, dysregulation of this program shifts excitability toward pathological states, particularly through altered M-channel (KCNQ) and BK-channel (KCNMA1/KCNMB2) function.

atomic_biological_processes.name: L-type calcium channel-mediated calcium signaling

citations.notes: CACNA1C genetic variation associated with brainstem volume and circuit development
Cacna1c deletion impairs hippocampal neurogenesis and behavioral outcomes

atomic_biological_processes.name: M-channel (KCNQ) suppression of neuronal excitability

citations.notes: KCNQ3 mutations associated with neonatal epilepsy and hyperexcitability

atomic_biological_processes.name: Fast-spiking interneuron potassium conductance

citations.notes: KCNC2 encodes Kv3-family potassium channel in fast-spiking neurons

atomic_biological_processes.name: BK calcium-activated potassium channel feedback inhibition

citations.notes: Calcium-activated potassium channels provide rapid feedback to stabilize firing frequency

predicted_cellular_impact: Increased intrinsic neuronal excitability in peritumoral neurons
Enhanced voltage deflections in soma in response to dendritic inputs
Reduced threshold for action potential generation
Impaired frequency-dependent regulation of firing
Greater susceptibility to paroxysmal depolarizing shifts and seizures
programs.evidence_summary: Peritumoral neurons show increased firing frequency slopes and enhanced intrinsic excitability during tumor progression. Computational modeling demonstrates that even modest changes in dendritic spine density, as observed in tumor-adjacent tissue, substantially increase the voltage deflection at the soma through enhanced synaptic conductance, effectively lowering the action potential threshold. Early tumor growth (14 days post-injection) shows transient elevation of intrinsic excitability preceding clinical seizure manifestation, suggesting dysregulation of voltage-gated channel function as an early biomarker.

citations.notes: Computational modeling of intrinsic excitability changes in tumor-adjacent neurons
CACNA1C as pleiotropic psychiatric disease gene
Cacna1c effects on hippocampal neurogenesis and behavior
Ion channel auxiliary subunits regulate voltage-gated channel function

programs.program_name: Axon Guidance and Neuronal Migration Control
programs.description: Secreted and membrane-bound guidance cues (SEMA3C, netrin ligands), their receptors (ROBO1, ROBO2, DCC, UNC5D), and cell adhesion molecules (CHL1, CNTNAP2, CNTN5, SEZ6L, SEZ6L2) that direct axonal projections and neuronal migration during development. SEMA3C binds plexin receptors to repel axons, while ROBO1/2 bind Slit ligands for repulsive guidance. DCC and UNC5D function as netrin receptors for attractive or repulsive guidance depending on co-receptor context. In astrocytoma, glioma cells exploit this guidance landscape to migrate along white matter tracts and infiltrate surrounding tissue directionally. Patient-derived glioblastoma cell lines migrate along axons toward neural spheroids in vitro.

atomic_biological_processes.name: Semaphorin-plexin-mediated repulsive axon guidance

citations.notes: SEMA3F semaphorin family members mediate repulsive axon guidance during neuronal development

atomic_biological_processes.name: Slit-roundabout repulsive guidance signaling

citations.notes: ROBO1 roundabout receptor mediates Slit-dependent repulsive axon guidance
ROBO2 encodes roundabout guidance receptor for axon guidance and migration

atomic_biological_processes.name: Netrin-attractive and repulsive guidance signaling

citations.notes: DCC and UNC5 function as netrin receptors with context-dependent guidance effects

atomic_biological_processes.name: Cell adhesion molecule-mediated axon-axon fasciculation and stabilization

citations.notes: L1CAM plays role in nervous system development including neuronal migration and differentiation
CNTNAP2 contactin-associated protein plays essential role in neural development

predicted_cellular_impact: Altered guidance of glioma cell migration along white matter tracts
Enhanced infiltrative behavior through co-option of axon guidance landscape
Directional migration of tumor cells toward neural target tissue
Disruption of normal axon-axon contacts and circuit organization
Altered peritumoral axonal integrity and network connectivity
programs.evidence_summary: Patient-derived glioblastoma cell lines migrate directionally along axons toward neural spheroids in live imaging assays, demonstrating that tumor cells actively exploit axon guidance mechanisms during infiltration. The expression of axon guidance receptors in glioma cells and the altered expression of guidance ligands in the tumor microenvironment suggest active remodeling of this program during tumorigenesis. Genetic studies in other cancers show that loss of repulsive guidance through SLIT-ROBO pathway disruption promotes migration, implicating this pathway in astrocytoma infiltration.

citations.notes: Glioblastoma cell migration directionally along axons toward neural spheroids
Slit-Robo signaling inhibition promotes cancer cell migration
ROBO2 function in axon guidance and cell migration
L1CAM role in nervous system development and potential in glioma
Netrin and Slit ligands required for receptor-mediated guidance

programs.description: Postsynaptic density (PSD) scaffolding proteins including membrane-associated guanylate kinases (DLG2), ankyrin repeat proteins (ANKS1B), MAGUK family members (MAGI3), and synapse-organizing proteins (LRRTM4, SHANK2) that organize the dense proteinaceous matrix underlying the postsynaptic membrane. These proteins coordinate positioning and stabilization of neurotransmitter receptors, signaling enzymes, and trans-synaptic adhesion molecules. DLG2 anchors NMDA receptors and scaffolds signaling complexes. LRRTM4 functions as postsynaptic cell adhesion molecule interacting with presynaptic neurexins. In glioma-adjacent neurons, increased dendritic spine density requires coordinated assembly of new postsynaptic densities.

atomic_biological_processes.name: PSD-93-mediated NMDA receptor anchoring and signaling complex organization

citations.notes: DLG2 (PSD-93) anchors NMDA receptors and organizes postsynaptic signaling complexes

atomic_biological_processes.name: Ankyrin repeat protein-based postsynaptic organization

citations.notes: ANKS1B localizes to dendritic spines and interacts with postsynaptic proteins

atomic_biological_processes.name: Trans-synaptic adhesion through neurexin-ligand interactions

citations.notes: CNTNAP2 member of neurexin superfamily plays essential role in neural development

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced postsynaptic density assembly at new dendritic spines
Increased synaptic strength through receptor organization and clustering
Altered dendritic spine stability and morphology
Dysregulated synaptic plasticity signaling
Potential links between synaptic organization and tumor cell proliferation
programs.evidence_summary: Glioma-adjacent neurons exhibit increased dendritic spine density, which requires corresponding assembly of new postsynaptic densities. Recent studies using advanced imaging reveal altered postsynaptic nanostructure in models of neurodevelopmental disorders featuring synaptic dysfunction. The scaffolding proteins DLG2 and related MAGUKs regulate both synaptic function and cell proliferation, suggesting functional links between aberrant synaptic organization and tumor-cell proliferation signals in low-grade gliomas.

citations.notes: Postsynaptic scaffolding proteins in synaptic organization and nanostructure
Increased dendritic spine density in tumor-adjacent neurons
CNTNAP2 in neural development and organization
PSD-95 family and Homer proteins organize postsynaptic density

programs.program_name: RNA Splicing Regulation and Neuronal Differentiation
programs.description: Splicing regulators (SRRM4, RBFOX1, CELF4) controlling alternative splicing patterns critical for neuronal development and plasticity. SRRM4 promotes inclusion of neuron-specific exons and drives differentiation toward neuronal fate. RBFOX1 regulates alternative splicing of neuronal genes including those involved in stress response and BDNF/TRKB signaling, with loss of function leading to disrupted stress response mechanisms. CELF4 regulates alternative splicing particularly during neuronal development. Coordinated developmental changes in splicing factor expression drive transitions from embryonic to adult isoforms. In astrocytoma, dysregulation of splicing programs may alter balance between pro-survival and pro-death isoforms.

atomic_biological_processes.name: SRRM4-mediated neuronal differentiation through neuron-specific splicing

citations.notes: SRRM4 neuronal-specific splicing regulator promotes neuron-specific exon inclusion during differentiation

atomic_biological_processes.name: RBFOX1-controlled stress response splicing

citations.notes: RBFOX1 loss of function disrupts BDNF/TRKB and CRH signaling leading to altered stress response
RBFOX1 regulates RNA splicing and transcriptional networks in human neuronal development

atomic_biological_processes.name: CELF4-mediated splicing during neuronal development

citations.notes: CELF4 CUGBP family splicing factor regulates alternative splicing during brain development

atomic_biological_processes.name: Developmental regulation of splicing factors through poison exon inclusion

citations.notes: UCR-associated poison exons trigger nonsense-mediated decay of splicing factor transcripts

predicted_cellular_impact: Aberrant production of embryonic isoforms in tumor cells and peritumoral neurons
Disrupted balance between pro-survival and pro-death protein isoforms
Altered stress response through dysregulated BDNF/TRKB signaling
Enhanced tumor cell plasticity through retention of developmental isoforms
Dysregulated ion channel and receptor isoform composition
programs.evidence_summary: Low-grade astrocytomas maintain expression of neural stem cell-associated genes and exhibit incomplete differentiation, suggesting disrupted developmental splicing programs. Developmental changes in splicing factor expression are essential for progression from embryonic to adult neural states. INSM1 drives intermediate progenitor identity in glioblastoma cells and is essential for tumorigenicity, suggesting reactivation of developmental transcriptional networks including those controlling splicing. Dysregulation of RBFOX1-controlled splicing of stress response genes could influence both tumor cell and peritumoral neuron responses to microenvironmental stress.

citations.notes: Ultraconserved regions regulate splicing factor expression and developmental alternative splicing programs
RBFOX1 regulates stress response mechanisms through BDNF/TRKB signaling
INSM1 drives intermediate progenitor state essential for glioblastoma tumorigenicity
SR and hnRNP splicing factor families regulate developmental alternative splicing

programs.description: Cytoskeletal regulators (ANK3, ABLIM2, VAV3, DYNC1I1, SPTBN4, PAK5) controlling actin polymerization, microtubule dynamics, and cell morphology. ANK3 links membrane proteins to spectrin-actin cytoskeleton. ABLIM2 modulates actin organization influencing dendritic morphology. VAV3 is Rho GTPase exchange factor regulating Rac1 activity and actin polymerization. DYNC1I1 transports vesicles along microtubules. SPTBN4 provides structural support for neuronal cytoskeleton. PAK5 functions downstream of Rho GTPases to regulate dendritic spine morphology through phosphorylation of LIMK and cofilin. In astrocytoma, enhanced dendritic spine density requires active cytoskeletal remodeling, and glioma cell migration requires extensive cytoskeletal remodeling.

atomic_biological_processes.name: Ankyrin-spectrin-actin linkage and cell morphology

citations.notes: ANK3 ankyrin-3 links integral membrane proteins to spectrin-actin cytoskeleton

atomic_biological_processes.name: Actin polymerization and dendritic spine morphogenesis

citations.notes: CDC42 and Rho GTPases regulate actin polymerization and dendritic spine dynamics

atomic_biological_processes.name: Microtubule-based intracellular transport

citations.notes: Dynein heavy chain involved in intracellular vesicle transport

atomic_biological_processes.name: Rho GTPase-effector signaling in migration and morphology

citations.notes: Loss of pericytes promotes mesenchymal transformation involving altered cytoskeletal organization
Mesenchymal glioma cell state characterized by Wnt and PAK signaling pathway activation

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced dendritic spine formation and remodeling in tumor-adjacent neurons
Increased glioma cell motility and infiltration through cytoskeletal remodeling
Mesenchymal transformation of tumor cells promoting migration
Altered dendritic and axonal morphology in peritumoral tissue
Dysregulated intracellular trafficking and organelle positioning
programs.evidence_summary: Glioma-adjacent neurons exhibit dramatically increased dendritic spine density, fundamentally dependent on coordinated actin polymerization and microtubule dynamics. Loss of pericytes in the glioma microenvironment leads to mesenchymal transformation of tumor cells involving upregulation of PAK and Rho GTPase signaling. Aberrant activation of these pathways promotes a motile phenotype compatible with enhanced infiltration. The intersection of cytoskeletal dynamics with oncogenic signaling pathways suggests links between structural remodeling and tumor cell proliferation.

citations.notes: Dendritic spine morphology alterations in tumor-adjacent neurons
Pericyte loss drives mesenchymal transformation in glioblastoma
Mesenchymal tumor cells interact with immune cells to drive invasive phenotype
Actin regulatory proteins downstream of PAK and Rho GTPases

programs.program_name: Extracellular Matrix Interactions and Cell Adhesion
programs.description: Extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins (FRAS1, EDIL3, NELL1) and cell adhesion molecules (TENM2, FAM155A, NTM, CHL1) mediating cell-ECM and cell-cell interactions. FRAS1 encodes ECM component important for tissue adhesion and structural organization. EDIL3 encodes EGF-like and discoidin domains involved in cell-cell interactions and vascular development. NELL1 upregulated during bone cell differentiation with emerging roles in neuronal development. TENM2 functions as trans-synaptic adhesion molecule and circuit regulator. FAM155A involved in developmental cell-cell interactions. NTM (neurotrimin) involved in cell-cell interactions regulating neuronal migration. These molecules establish cellular scaffold organizing tissue architecture and specifying cell-cell contacts.

atomic_biological_processes.name: ECM structural organization and tissue adhesion

citations.notes: ECM components dysregulated in glioblastoma compared to normal brain
Single-cell spatial profiling maps expression of nearly 400 ECM genes in GBM

atomic_biological_processes.name: Cell-cell recognition and trans-synaptic adhesion

citations.notes: Novel ECM ligand-receptor networks between GBM and stromal cells

atomic_biological_processes.name: Perivascular niche ECM organization

citations.notes: Perivascular niche characterized by specific ECM signatures and cellular organization

predicted_cellular_impact: Spatial organization of ECM in distinct tumor microenvironmental niches
Altered peritumoral neuron-ECM interactions affecting synaptic stability
Enhanced glioma cell-stromal cell interactions through dysregulated ECM
Disruption of normal tissue architecture in peritumoral zone
Remodeling of extracellular space promoting tumor infiltration
programs.evidence_summary: Spatial transcriptomic profiling reveals that ECM signaling pathways are extensively dysregulated in glioblastoma, with different GBM cell populations and stromal cell types showing largely non-overlapping ECM expression patterns. Vascular endothelial cells and immune cells in the perivascular niche express distinct ECM signatures supporting their specialized functions. The spatial organization of ECM components reflects the complex microarchitecture of glioblastomas where distinct cellular niches express different ECM components. Altered ECM composition disrupts perisynaptic matrix structure, contributing to synaptic reorganization in tumor-adjacent neurons.

citations.notes: ECM ligand-receptor networks in glioblastoma perivascular niche
Spatial profiling of matrisome identifies cell-specific ECM expression in GBM
Perivascular niche organization in glioblastoma
Major ECM components dysregulated in glioblastoma

programs.program_name: Neurotrophic Signaling and Growth Factor Cascades
programs.description: Receptor tyrosine kinases and growth factor signaling mediating survival, plasticity, and circuit development. ERBB4 encodes ErbB-4 receptor tyrosine kinase binding neuregulin ligands, particularly in parvalbumin-positive GABAergic interneurons. NRG1 and NRG3 encode neuregulin growth factors important for myelination, axon-glia interactions, and synaptic plasticity. RBFOX1-regulated BDNF/TRKB signaling controls stress response mechanisms. These pathways activate PI3K and MAPK cascades. In astrocytoma, dysregulated neurotrophic signaling promotes survival of tumor-supporting immune cells, drives tumor cell proliferation, and alters neurotrophic factor availability for peritumoral neurons.

atomic_biological_processes.name: ERBB4 receptor tyrosine kinase signaling in interneuron development

citations.notes: ERBB4 expressed in parvalbumin-positive interneurons, regulates conversion between microglial activation states

atomic_biological_processes.name: Neuregulin ligand signaling through ErbB receptors

citations.notes: NRG1 neuregulin family member enables ErbB-2 class receptor binding
Neuregulin-1 regulates microglial phenotype via ErbB4

atomic_biological_processes.name: BDNF/TRKB signaling in stress response and neuroprotection

citations.notes: RBFOX1 regulates BDNF/TRKB signaling affecting stress response and psychiatric health

predicted_cellular_impact: Altered interneuron survival and functional integration in peritumoral tissue
Enhanced alternatively activated macrophage polarization in tumor microenvironment
Disrupted neurotrophic support for peritumoral neurons
Tumor cell proliferation through aberrant neurotrophic receptor activation
Enhanced immune cell recruitment and polarization toward tumor-supportive states
programs.evidence_summary: NRG1-ERBB4 signaling regulates conversion between microglial activation states, promoting anti-inflammatory M2 phenotype through inhibition of NF-kappaB pathway. In the tumor microenvironment, dysregulation of neurotrophic signaling contributes to skewing of immune cells toward tumor-supporting phenotypes. Pediatric high-grade gliomas show NTRK fusion events with constitutively active neurotrophic receptor signaling driving oncogenic transformation. Altered neurotrophic factor signaling in peritumoral zones affects local neuronal survival and plasticity.

citations.notes: ERBB4-NRG1 signaling in microglial phenotype regulation
RBFOX1 and BDNF/TRKB signaling in stress response mechanisms
NTRK fusion events in pediatric high-grade gliomas
BDNF and TRKB as key components of neurotrophic signaling

programs.program_name: Developmental Transcriptional Regulation and Neural Identity
programs.description: Transcriptional control of neuronal and glial identity specification and differentiation state maintenance. While input gene list contains few direct transcription factors, splicing regulators (RBFOX1, SRRM4) and their targets provide indirect transcriptional effects. Recent research reveals that INSM1 transcription factor drives intermediate progenitor cell-like state in glioblastoma, governs plasticity and tumorigenicity. This program reflects reactivation of developmental transcriptional networks in malignant gliomas. Low-grade astrocytomas maintain higher expression of neural stem cell markers, suggesting incomplete execution of differentiation programs. High-grade astrocytomas show mixed glial-neuronal marker expression indicating profound dysregulation of transcriptional identity programs.

atomic_biological_processes.name: INSM1-driven intermediate progenitor cell identity in glioblastoma

citations.notes: INSM1 governs intermediate progenitor state that drives glioblastoma tumorigenicity and plasticity

atomic_biological_processes.name: Splicing factor control of developmental transcriptional programs

citations.notes: Developmental splicing program changes coordinate with brain maturation

atomic_biological_processes.name: Dysregulated neuronal vs glial lineage specification

citations.notes: Triple mutant neural stem cells express intermediate progenitor markers and tumorigenicity

predicted_cellular_impact: Reactivation of developmental neuronal differentiation programs in glial tumors
Maintenance of neural stem cell-like state preventing terminal differentiation
Mixed or failed glial-neuronal lineage specification
Enhanced cellular plasticity and adaptability to therapeutic pressure
Expression of developmental isoforms of ion channels and receptors
programs.evidence_summary: Glioblastomas exhibit reactivation of developmental transcriptional networks, particularly those governing intermediate progenitor cell identity through INSM1. INSM1 is highly expressed in human glioblastoma tumors and, during normal cortical development, specifically in intermediate progenitor cells that give rise to neurons. INSM1 knockdown disrupts oncogenic gene expression and reduces tumorigenicity, highlighting functional importance of this developmental state. Low-grade astrocytomas maintain higher expression of neural stem cell markers and show incomplete oligodendroglial differentiation, suggesting that developmental programs remain partially active or terminal differentiation is blocked.

citations.notes: INSM1 governs intermediate progenitor state essential for glioblastoma pathogenesis
Developmental regulation of splicing programs controlling neuronal differentiation
Core transcriptional regulators of neural differentiation programs

clustering_basis: Cell type and tissue-specific expression patterns
method.notes: Gene programs identified through systematic analysis of functional literature, PubMed searches, and pathway databases. Programs clustered based on shared biological processes, regulatory networks, and functional interdependencies. Each program represents a coherent biological function relevant to both normal neural physiology and dysregulation in astrocytoma contexts. Prioritized well-established functions with strong literature support while highlighting emerging evidence where contextually relevant.
